item.title: ‘Pervasive racism’ blamed for failure to commemorate black and Asian troops
item.description: Thousands of black and Asian British Empire troops were not remembered properly, a report says.

item.title: Climate change: Biden summit to push for immediate action
item.description: Forty world leaders will be urged to increase their carbon-cutting actions at US virtual summit.

item.title: Covid: India sets global record for new cases amid oxygen shortage
item.description: The country records 314,835 new daily cases as Delhi hospitals fear running out of oxygen in hours.

item.title: Billionaire Sir James Dyson moves residency back to the UK
item.description: Sir James faced criticism in 2019 over relocating his company's global headquarters to Singapore.

item.title: Marcus Rashford's budget cookery serves up fish finger sandwich
item.description: The footballer and food poverty campaigner is launching a new affordable meals project.

item.title: Covid-19: Call for PM-Dyson probe and driving tests like 'gold dust'
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday morning.

item.title: Driving tests resume but getting a date like 'gold dust'
item.description: Most centres are currently booked up until August, with a 420,000 backlog because of the pandemic.

item.title: India's second wave: 'We were not prepared'
item.description: The Covid-19 pandemic is accelerating in India beyond anywhere else in the world.

item.title: Super League on standby, says Real Madrid president
item.description: The European Super League is on "standby" despite nine of the 12 founding teams withdrawing, says Real Madrid president Florentino Perez.

item.title: Church told it must shortlist ethnic minorities for senior posts
item.description: Failing to act would have "devastating effects" on the future of the Church of England, a report says.

item.title: Italian hospital employee accused of skipping work for 15 years
item.description: The hospital worker in southern Italy earned €538,000 while not going into work, media say.

item.title: MI5 joins Instagram to bust martini-drinking stereotypes
item.description: Launching the account, MI5's boss says: "You can insert your own joke about whether we will be following you."

item.title: The Papers: George Floyd's legacy and EU 'to welcome tourists'
item.description: No one story dominates the papers, but some reflect on racism in US after Derek Chauvin's conviction.

item.title: London Grammar: 'Men aren't told what to wear, so why was I?'
item.description: Hannah Reid, from London Grammar, tells Radio 1 Newsbeat that music is still a sexist industry.

item.title: ASMR: Why is it being used more in the music industry?
item.description: Why ASMR is becoming more used within the music industry.

item.title: Climate Basics: Your carbon footprint explained
item.description: BBC Reality Check's Chris Morris explains how changing three aspects of how you live can make the biggest dent to your carbon footprint.

item.title: Met Office and Microsoft to build climate supercomputer
item.description: The Met Office will work with Microsoft on a supercomputer which will help model climate change.

item.title: Is it the end of the line for landline phones?
item.description: Four million homes have dropped their fixed line phones since 2000 a trend which may see a post-pandemic boost.

item.title: What's gone wrong with Australia's vaccine rollout?
item.description: The country has been far slower than others including the UK and the US to immunise its population.

item.title: Oscars 2021: Why Two Distant Strangers is 'important and necessary'
item.description: The Oscar-nominated film tells of a black man forced to relive his killing by a US police officer.

item.title: Could this lidless paper cup cut coffee waste?
item.description: A new crop of coffee companies have solutions to cut waste in their industry.

item.title: Post Office scandal: What the Horizon saga is all about
item.description: The background to the case of sub-postmasters whose convictions were based on evidence from faulty IT.

item.title: Scottish election 2021: Can unionists block another independence referendum?
item.description: In the second of two Scottish election pieces, we look at the parties opposing another vote on independence.

item.title: Big Dog's Backyard Ultra: The toughest, weirdest race you've never heard of
item.description: The format might be simple - winning this race is anything but. Big Dog's Backyard Ultra is an unusually punishing challenge.

item.title: Aston Villa 1-2 Manchester City: Pep Guardiola's side eight points from Premier League title
item.description: Manchester City move closer to becoming Premier League champions as they beat Aston Villa in a match where both sides end with 10 men.

item.title: Man Utd & Liverpool owners apologise to fans for ESL involvement
item.description: Manchester United and Liverpool owners apologise to supporters for their involvement in a proposed European Super League.

item.title: British and Irish Lions: Maro Itoje backed by Sam Warburton to captain 2021 side
item.description: England's Maro Itoje is backed to lead the British and Irish Lions against South Africa this summer by the man who captained the last two tours.

item.title: Chelsea stay top of WSL after Man City draw - report & highlight
item.description: Leaders Chelsea remain in control of the Women's Super League title race after a thrilling draw at Manchester City.

item.title: Griffiths denies Aberdeen victory against Celtic
item.description: Stephen Glass was "proud" of his players despite Leigh Griffiths' stoppage-time goal extending Celtic's unbeaten run against Aberdeen at Pittodrie to 11 games.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel through two south London boroughs are being urged to take a Covid-19 test.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Is the Australia-NZ travel bubble the way ahead?
item.description: Australia and New Zealand have quarantine-free travel, but will other countries follow their lead?

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Pubs and gyms will reopen in Scotland on Monday, as lockdown restrictions ease significantly.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: A traffic light system ranking foreign countries by coronavirus risk is to be introduced - the rules on UK holidays are also easing.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs have reopened, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs, cafes and restaurants in England are open for customers seated outdoors.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: What are the Indian, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Cases are being found in the UK and the changes the virus is undergoing are concerning.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 45 or over in England are being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: 'My sister took her life, petrified at facing her ex in court'
item.description: Gemma Robinson died just days before she was due to see her ex-partner in court.

item.title: Covid-19 in India: Why second coronavirus wave is devastating
item.description: A deadly second wave has overrun hospitals and even crematoriums in India.

item.title: The disabled doctors not believed by their colleagues
item.description: People often feel nervous when they visit a doctor, but what if you are a doctor but your colleagues don't believe you're ill?

item.title: The homeless drug addict who became a professor
item.description: Jesse Thistle, a high school dropout, overcame addiction and homelessness to pursue an academic career.

item.title: Nil-by-mouth foodie: The chef who will never eat again
item.description: Loretta Harmes hasn't eaten or tasted food for six years, but she hasn't lost her passion for cooking.
